items.synopsis: The Mataranka Hotel stopped serving takeaway alcohol to Indigenous people during a "community-led", short-term ban following the death of a woman in the nearby Jilkminggan community.

title.children: NT pub refuses to sell Indigenous people takeaway alcohol in short-term, 'community-led' ban

image.altText: A smiling teenage boy holds his hand to his chin in a thinking gesture while standing outdoors in front of a shop.

title.children: 'We did all we could': Noah was desperate for gender care. He died waiting for help

items.synopsis: We wanted the story to reflect the weight of evidence, but were acutely aware that the science is new and evolving. We believe we got the balance right, writes Mark Maley.

title.children: Why Four Corners had to investigate the bitter and polarised transgender debate

image.altText: Man smiling while holding two glass awards in front of a red banner

image.altText: A woman in a floral shirt sits at a restaurant table.

items.synopsis: Scientists are still working to unpack the mystery of why some people keep catching the virus while others seem to be resistant. In the meantime, people like Marion have been left with more questions than answers.

items.synopsis: The Ashes were within reach for Australia for a fleeting moment on day four at Headingley, but it missed its most critical moment and allowed England to keep this outrageous series alive.

title.children: How Australia missed the moment that could have wrapped up the Ashes early

title.children: Three teenage boys injured, one critically, after car rolls down embankment in Brisbane

items.synopsis: A weevil smaller than a grain of rice has been released into waterways infested with cabomba weed, a South American plant that has been wreaking havoc in several states and territories.

title.children: Ancient enemy unleashed against one of Australia's worst aquatic weeds

items.synopsis: Lisa is one of thousands of British police officers looking to move to Australia, but because her daughter has Down syndrome her visa application is likely to be rejected — a feature of the Migration Act.

title.children: Australia's migration law labelled discriminatory, but entirely legal, because of this major caveat

image.altText: A blurred photo of the share trading boards at the Australian stock exchange

items.synopsis: Local stocks make modest gains. The RBA's assistant governor of economics will join Westpac as chief economist. US jobs numbers were below forecasts but wages growth was stronger. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX rises, Luci Ellis to leave RBA for Westpac, mixed messages on US jobs market

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The local share market has given up some of its early gains and is just modestly higher around lunchtime. Energy stocks remain the standout, while the major miners are now mixed, with Rio Tinto shares slipping into the red. Here are the biggest percentage moves on the ASX 200: Top 5 Monadelphous Group: +4.7% Bellevue Gold: +3.6% Silver Lake Resources: +3.3% Regis Resources: +3.1% Block: +3.1% Bottom 5 Tabcorp: -3.4% Magellan Financial: -3.1% Cromwell Property: -1.8% Transurban: -1.6% Atlas Arteria: -1.5% Around the region, Asian markets are mixed with gains in Hong Kong, Shanghai and Seoul while stocks in Tokyo have fallen. It follows some weaker-than-expected economic data out of China, with consumer prices barely budging from a year earlier.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX losing steam into lunchtime

children.content: The local share market has given up some of its early gains and is just modestly higher around lunchtime.
Energy stocks remain the standout, while the major miners are now mixed, with Rio Tinto shares slipping into the red.
Here are the biggest percentage moves on the ASX 200:
Around the region, Asian markets are mixed with gains in Hong Kong, Shanghai and Seoul while stocks in Tokyo have fallen.
It follows some weaker-than-expected economic data out of China, with consumer prices barely budging from a year earlier.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We're just getting into today's trade and it looks like it's living up to its promise at this early stage. About 20 minutes in and the ASX 200 and the All Ordinaries have gained around half a per cent. The major banks, miners and energy stocks are all higher, with just 55 of the top 200 stocks in the red. Here are the biggest percentage moves so far: Top 5 Monadelphous Group: +5.3% Block: +4.2% Pilbara Minerals: +3.8% De Grey Mining: +3.5% Syrah Resources: +3.4% Bottom 5 Tabcorp: -2.7% Ingenia Communities: -1.4% Magellan Financial: -1.4% Mirvac: -1.3% Region Re: -1.1%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Positive start for local stocks

children.content: We're just getting into today's trade and it looks like it's living up to its promise at this early stage.
About 20 minutes in and the ASX 200 and the All Ordinaries have gained around half a per cent.
The major banks, miners and energy stocks are all higher, with just 55 of the top 200 stocks in the red.
Here are the biggest percentage moves so far:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Some moves announced today in the world of Australian economics. Westpac's long-standing chief economist Bill Evans will be moving to a new role as of next year. And the bank's new chief economist will be current Reserve Bank assistant governor of economics Luci Ellis. Mr Evans will become Westpac's senior economic adviser, after more than 30 years in the group chief economist role. "Bill joined Westpac in the midst of the 1991 recession and since then has been a trusted voice in Australia through every economic cycle," Westpac CEO Peter King said. "Luci is a highly qualified and respected economist who will build on Bill's legacy of providing quality economic forecasts for Westpac customers." Ms Ellis will join the bank in October.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Reserve Bank economics head to join Westpac

children.content: Some moves announced today in the world of Australian economics.
Westpac's long-standing chief economist Bill Evans will be moving to a new role as of next year.
And the bank's new chief economist will be current Reserve Bank assistant governor of economics Luci Ellis.
Mr Evans will become Westpac's senior economic adviser, after more than 30 years in the group chief economist role.
"Bill joined Westpac in the midst of the 1991 recession and since then has been a trusted voice in Australia through every economic cycle," Westpac CEO Peter King said.
"Luci is a highly qualified and respected economist who will build on Bill's legacy of providing quality economic forecasts for Westpac customers."
Ms Ellis will join the bank in October.

image.altText: The hand of woman wearing a grey long sleeve top rests on her patterned skirt

items.synopsis: Mary-Lou says her son used to park his car in the driveway to block her in her home before demanding money. Now the trialled program that helped her escape elder abuse is ending.

title.children: Mary-Lou says elder abuse by her son left her 'humiliated, horrified and alone'

items.synopsis: Older people downsizing to smaller homes is one way housing stock can be used more efficiently but despite government moves to make it more attractive financially, barriers still exist.

title.children: Downsizing could be part of the solution to the housing crisis. So why aren't more people doing it?

image.altText: Nakkiah Lui wearing a brown blazer dress, not smiling, looking at camera

items.synopsis: When you think of a farmer, what image comes to mind? Nakkiah Lui asks that question on her latest podcast First Eat. If you envisioned a white man in an Akubra, you're not alone. Here's why that's an issue and the impact on your dinner plate.

title.children: How the food you eat could be making you sick and what to do about it

image.altText: Compost in a bin

items.synopsis: About 7.6 million tonnes of unnecessary food waste is thrown in the bin by Australians every year.

title.children: Food waste is costing Australian households up to $3,000 a year

title.children: Legally blind woman left anxious and in tears after rideshare drivers refuse to pick her up 23 times in six weeks

items.synopsis: The families of those on board have not heard from them since the three boats left Senegal on the dangerous migration route about two weeks ago.

title.children: At least 300 migrants missing at sea near Spain's Canary Islands, aid group says

image.altText: Oscar Piastri stands on a stage, with his back to a massive crowd, smiling in his Orange outfit

items.synopsis: The Australian driver was "very happy" with fourth place behind Max Verstappen at Silverstone, while Hollywood A-lister Brad Pitt made an appearance on the track.

image.altText: A young woman with dark brown hair streaked with turquoise smiles softly.

items.synopsis: A rise in the number of young people without a regular GP has health experts concerned it could leave them at higher risk of developing chronic health conditions later in life.

title.children: Zali was quoted up to $1,200 for a consult. Experts say young people are ditching GPs and specialists over cost
